abbreviations.EMIC: Earth System Model of Intermediate Complexity

children.value: 1. Energy exchange mechanisms at the Earth’s surface

children.label: 1. Energy exchange mechanisms at the Earth’s surface

children.value: The surface of the Earth is the boundary between the atmosphere and the land, ocean, or ice. Understanding the energy fluxes across the surface are very important for three main reasons:
We are most interested in the climate at the surface because we live at the surface.
The surface energy budget determines how much energy is available to evaporate water and moisten the atmosphere.
Air-sea energy fluxes set the thermal structure of the oceans, which in turn act to redistribute energy around the planet, with many important consequences for climate.
The energy budget at the surface is more complex that the budget at the top of the atmosphere. At the
the only energy transfer mechanisms are radiative (shortwave and
gwave). At the surface, in addition to radiation we need to consider fluxes of energy by conduction and by convection of heat and moisture through turbulent fluid motion.
jor terms in the surface energy budget

children.label: Major terms in the surface energy budget

children.value: net upward energy flux at the surface

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: As we mentioned back in a previous
, there are four principal contributions to

children.html: FSF_SFS​
FS≠0F_S \ne 0FS​=0

children.value: , there is a net flux of energy between the atmosphere and the surface below. This implies either that there is heat storage / release occuring below the surface (e.g. warming or cooling of water, melting of snow and ice), and/or there is horizontal heat transport by fluid motions occuring below the surface (ocean circu
Minor terms in the surface energy budget

children.label: Minor terms in the surface energy budget

children.value: All of these terms are small globally but can be significant locally or seasonally.
Latent heat of fusion required for melting ice and snow
Conversion of the kinetic energy of winds and waves to thermal energy
Heat transport by precipitation, if precipitation is at a different temperature than the surface
Biological uptake of solar energy through photosynthesis
Biological release of energy through oxidation (respiration, decay, fires)
Geothermal heat sources (hot springs, volcanoes, etc.)
Anthropogenic heat released through fossil fuel burning and nuclear power generation.

children.label: 2. The surface energy budget in CESM simulations

children.value: We will examine the surface budget in our fully coupled
ions. The advantage of looking at surface fluxes in a model rather than observations is that the model fluxes are completely consistent with the model climate, so that the net flux

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: will be a meaningful measure of the heat storage in the system.
The model also gives us an opportunity to look at how the surface budget reponds to global warming under a transient increase in CO

children.html: 2_22​

children.value: ions we worked with in the lecture on the
Transient and Equilibrium Response of the CESM

%matplotlib inline
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import xarray as xr
from climlab import constants as const
import cartopy.crs as ccrs
from cartopy.util import add_cyclic_point

casenames = {'cpl_control': 'cpl_1850_f19',
             'cpl_CO2ramp': 'cpl_CO2ramp_f19',
             'som_control': 'som_1850_f19',
             'som_2xCO2':   'som_1850_2xCO2',
            }
# The path to the THREDDS server, should work from anywhere
basepath = 'http://thredds.atmos.albany.edu:8080/thredds/dodsC/CESMA/'
# For better performance if you can access the roselab_rit filesystem (e.g. from JupyterHub)
# basepath = '/roselab_rit/cesm_archive/'

# Topography data, just used for plotting
topo = xr.open_dataset(basepath+'som_input/USGS-gtopo30_1.9x2.5_remap_c050602.nc')

casepaths = {}
for name in casenames:
    casepaths[name] = basepath + casenames[name] + '/concatenated/'

# make a dictionary of all the CAM atmosphere output
atm = {}
for name in casenames:
    path = casepaths[name] + casenames[name] + '.cam.h0.nc'
    print('Attempting to open the dataset ', path)
    atm[name] = xr.open_dataset(path)

# extract the last 10 years from the slab ocean control simulation
# and the last 20 years from the coupled control
nyears_slab = 10
nyears_cpl = 20
clim_slice_slab = slice(-(nyears_slab*12),None)
clim_slice_cpl = slice(-(nyears_cpl*12),None)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
Attempting to open the dataset  http://thredds.atmos.albany.edu:8080/thredds/dodsC/CESMA/cpl_1850_f19/concatenated/cpl_1850_f19.cam.h0.nc
Attempting to open the dataset  http://thredds.atmos.albany.edu:8080/thredds/dodsC/CESMA/cpl_CO2ramp_f19/concatenated/cpl_CO2ramp_f19.cam.h0.nc
Attempting to open the dataset  http://thredds.atmos.albany.edu:8080/thredds/dodsC/CESMA/som_1850_f19/concatenated/som_1850_f19.cam.h0.nc
Attempting to open the dataset  http://thredds.atmos.albany.edu:8080/thredds/dodsC/CESMA/som_1850_2xCO2/concatenated/som_1850_2xCO2.cam.h0.nc

children.value:
lat = atm['cpl_control'].lat
lon = atm['cpl_control'].lon
lev = atm['cpl_control'].lev

#  Surface energy budget terms, all defined as positive up (from ocean to atmosphere)
surface_budget = {}
monthly_surface_budget = {}

for (name, run) in atm.items():
    fields = xr.Dataset()
    fields['LHF'] = run.LHFLX
    fields['SHF'] = run.SHFLX
    fields['LWsfc'] = run.FLNS
    fields['LWsfc_clr'] = run.FLNSC
    fields['SWsfc'] = -run.FSNS
    fields['SWsfc_clr'] = -run.FSNSC
    fields['SnowFlux'] = ((run.PRECSC+run.PRECSL)
                           *const.rho_w*const.Lhfus)

    clim_budget = fields.isel(time=clim_slice_cpl)
    # net upward radiation from surface
    clim_budget['NetRad'] = clim_budget.LWsfc + clim_budget.SWsfc
    clim_budget['NetRad_clr'] = clim_budget.LWsfc_clr + clim_budget.SWsfc_clr
    # net upward surface heat flux
    clim_budget['Net'] = (clim_budget.NetRad + clim_budget.LHF + 
                     clim_budget.SHF + clim_budget.SnowFlux)
    
    budget = clim_budget.mean(dim='time')
    monthly_budget = clim_budget.groupby(clim_budget.time.dt.month).mean()
    
    surface_budget[name] = budget
    monthly_surface_budget[name] = monthly_budget

#   Here we take advantage of xarray!
#   We can simply subtract the two xarray.Dataset objects 
#   to get anomalies for every term
surface_budget['anom'] = surface_budget['cpl_CO2ramp'] - surface_budget['cpl_control']
monthly_surface_budget['anom'] = monthly_surface_budget['cpl_CO2ramp'] - monthly_surface_budget['cpl_control']
Plot maps of the annual mean net upward flux

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.label: Plot maps of the annual mean net upward flux F_S (control and anomaly after warming)

children.value:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,5))

ax1 = fig.add_subplot(1,2,1, projection=ccrs.Robinson())
field = surface_budget['cpl_control'].Net
# add cyclic point so cartopy doesn't show a white strip at zero longitude
wrap_data, wrap_lon = add_cyclic_point(field.values, coord=field.lon, axis=field.dims.index('lon'))


cax1 = ax1.pcolormesh(wrap_lon, field.lat, wrap_data, 
                        cmap=plt.cm.seismic, vmin=-200., vmax=200.,
                        transform=ccrs.PlateCarree())
ax1.set_title('Annual mean net surface heat flux (+ up) - CESM control')

ax2 = fig.add_subplot(1,2,2, projection=ccrs.Robinson())
cax2 = ax2.pcolormesh(lon, lat, surface_budget['anom'].Net,
                    cmap=plt.cm.seismic, vmin=-30., vmax=30.,
                     transform=ccrs.PlateCarree())
ax2.set_title('Anomaly after 1%/year CO2 ramp')

for ax in [ax1, ax2]:
    ax.set_global(); ax.coastlines();
for cax in [cax1, cax2]:
    plt.colorbar(cax, orientation='horizontal', label='W m$^{-2}$')
Some notable points about the control state:
The net flux over all land surfaces is very close to zero!

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: must be balanced by heat transport.

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: over the oceans is essentially just the prescribed q-flux that we have imposed on the slab ocean to represent ocean heat transport.
We have looked at maps like this before, back when we
introduced the slab ocean version of the CESM
lecture on decompositions of poleward heat transport
Net heat uptake by the oceans occurs mostly a
g the equator and the cold tongues on the eastern sides of the tropical basins.
Net heat release from oceans to atmosphere occurs mostly in mid- to high
itudes. Hot spots include the Gulf Stream and Kuroshio regions on the western sides of the mid-
itude basins, as well as the subpolar North Atlantic. These features are largely determined by ocean dynamics.

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: is very small in most locations.
This indicates that the model has reached quasi-equilibrium. Non-zero changes in

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: We can see the dominant regions of ocean heat uptake in the North Atlantic as well as the Southern Ocean showing up as negative anomalies in

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: Variation of energy balance components with

children.label: Variation of energy balance components with latitude

children.value: In these graphs, the curve labeled “Net” is the net flux

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: . It is just the zonal average of the maps from the previous figure, and shows the ocean heat uptake at the equator and release in mid- to high
More interestingly, these graphs show the contribution of the various terms to

children.html: FSF_SFS​

children.value: . They are all plotted as positive up. A
Key points about the control simu
Solar radiation acts to warm the surface everywhere.
Note that this is a net shortwave flux, so it is the amount that is actually absorbed by the surface after accounting for the reflected fraction.
All other mechanisms act to cool the surface.
Latent heat flux is dominant over sensible heat flux at most
itudes except close to the poles.
gwave radiation also acts to cool the surface.
This is the residual between the surface emissions (essentially

children.html: σ Ts4\sigma~T_s^4σ Ts4​

children.value: ) and the back-radiation from the atmosphere.
gwave radiation is negative at most
This implies that the downwelling back-radiation increases faster than the upwelling surface emissions.
This is a signature of greenhouse warming! Both the upwelling and downwelling beams increase with warming. But the downwelling beam also increases because of the CO

children.html: 2_22​

children.value: -induced increase in emissivity of the atmosphere.
So the surface is warmed by excess
This warming is largely balanced by increased evaporation (red curve)!
There are also significant changes in shortwave radiation. We could use the modeled clear-sky diagnostics to infer which of these changes are due to clouds.
The negative shortwave anomalies in high
itudes are consistent with surface albedo feedback and loss of ice and snow.
We will compute the budgets for the months of January and July, and plot their differences.

fieldlist = ['SWsfc', 'LWsfc', 'LHF', 'SHF', 'Net']
fig,axes = plt.subplots(1,2,figsize=(16,5))
for field in fieldlist:
    axes[0].plot(lat, julminusjan_budget['cpl_control'][field].mean(dim='lon'), label=field)
axes[0].set_title('Components of JUL-JAN surface energy budget (+ up) - CESM control')
for field in fieldlist:
    axes[1].plot(lat, julminusjan_budget['anom'][field].mean(dim='lon'), label=field)
axes[1].set_title('Anomaly after CO2 doubling')
for ax in axes:
    ax.set_xlim(-90, 90)
    ax.grid()
    ax.legend()
    ax.set_ylabel('W m$^{-2}$')
    ax.set_xlabel('Latitude')
Seasonally, the dominant balance by far is between solar radiation and heat storage!
3. Sensible and Latent Heat Fluxes in the boundary layer

The Bowen ratio for wet surfaces

children.label: The Bowen ratio for wet surfaces

children.value: Over a water surface or a very wet land surface, we may assume that the mixing ratio of water vapor at the surface is equal to the saturation mixing ratio

Let’s approximate the mixing ratio for
at the reference height through a first-order Taylor series expansion:
q_a^* \approx q_s^*(T_s) + \frac{\partial q^*}{\partial T} \left( T_a - T_s \right)

children.label: The equilibrium Bowen ratio (for saturated air)

children.value: if the boundary layer air is saturated

children.html: r=1r=1r=1

children.value: When the surface and the air at the reference level are saturated, the Bowen ratio approaches the value

children.html: BeB_eBe​

children.value: , which is called the equilibrium Bowen ratio. We presume that the flux of moisture from the boundary layer to the free atmosphere is sufficient to just balance the upward flux of moisture from the surface so that the humidity at the reference height is in equilibrium at the saturation value.
Recall that from the Clausius-Claperyon re
ion, the rate of change of the saturation mixing ratio is itself a strong function of temperature:

children.html: ∂q∗∂T=q∗(T)LRv T2\frac{\partial q^*}{\partial T} = q^*(T) \frac{L}{R_v ~ T^2}∂T∂q∗​=q∗(T)Rv​ T2L​
q∗q^*q∗
TTT

children.value: far outweighs the inverse square dependence, so the
equilibrium Bowen ratio decreases roughly exponentially with temperature
The following code reproduces Figure 4.10 of

from climlab.utils.thermo import qsat
T = np.linspace(-40, 40) + const.tempCtoK
qstar = qsat(T, const.ps)  # in kg / kg

def Be(T):
    qstar = qsat(T, const.ps)  # in kg / kg
    dqstardT = qstar * const.Lhvap / const.Rv / T**2
    return const.cp / const.Lhvap / dqstardT

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.semilogy(T + const.tempKtoC, qstar*1000, label='$q^*$')
ax.semilogy(T + const.tempKtoC, Be(T), label='$B_e$')
ax.grid()
ax.set_xlabel('Temperature (degC)')
ax.legend(loc='upper center')
ax.set_title('Saturation specific humidity (g/kg) and equilibrium Bowen ratio');
Equilibrium Bowen ratio is near 1 at 0ºC, and decreases to about 0.2 at 30ºC.
ive humidity is decreased from 1 to smaller values,
The equilibrium Bowen ratio is the
maximum possible Bowen ratio for a wet surface
Actual Bowen ratio over a wet surface will generally be smaller than

children.value: , because the air is usually not saturated.
Because of the strong temperature dependence of the saturation specific humidity:

Bo_control = (surface_budget['cpl_control'].SHF / 
              surface_budget['cpl_control'].LHF)
Be_control = Be(atm['cpl_control'].TS.isel(time=clim_slice_cpl).mean(dim='time'))

fig,axes = plt.subplots(1,3,figsize=(16,4))
cax1 = axes[0].pcolormesh(lon, lat, Bo_control,
                    vmin=0., vmax=5. )
fig.colorbar(cax1, ax=axes[0])
axes[0].set_title('$B_o$ (CESM control)', fontsize=20)
cax2 = axes[1].pcolormesh(lon, lat, Be_control,
                    vmin=0., vmax=5. )
fig.colorbar(cax2, ax=axes[1])
axes[1].set_title('$B_e$ (CESM control)', fontsize=20)
cax3 = axes[2].pcolormesh(lon, lat, (Bo_control - Be_control),
                    cmap='seismic', vmin=-10., vmax=10. )
fig.colorbar(cax3, ax=axes[2])
axes[2].set_title('$B_o - B_e$ (CESM control)', fontsize=20)
for ax in axes:
    ax.set_xlim(0, 360)
    ax.set_ylim(-90, 90)
    ax.contour( lon, lat, topo.variables['LANDFRAC'][:], [0.5], colors='k');
On the difference plot, the blue colors indicate the actual Bowen ratio is smaller than the equilibrium Bowen ratio. This will typically occur for
The red colors indicate the actual Bowen ratio is larger than the equilibrium Bowen ratio. This typically occurs for
where there is not enough water available to satisfy the energetic demand for evaporation.
